content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												The simulator looks fantastic, the steam edition is a better version in terms of performance than the boxed version of the FSX.Some updates are coming out, something that the boxed FSX has not seen in a while.On the other hand, the reason for these updates is due to the fact that the FSX:SE seems to have issues with many addons, some of the addons that are widely used by the FSX community, seem to not work in SE, example would be the PMDG airplanes, which simply do not work.All FSX:SE needs is to have some updates injected to deal with the addons, and the developers also changing their addons to work with FSX:SE and this would be a very very strong product.FSX:SE also finally allows for shared cockpit, so you can have a commander and first officer working together to fly and land airplanes.I've used this feature, but it's not working well, it always takes about 2 hours of frustration disconnecting and connecting, recreating sessions until everyhting works, but when it does, it's a fantastic experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Having started to get my private license, I have been wanting a solid simulator.  This sim is what my school uses when actual flight isn't ideal, so when it came to steam, and at a reasonable price, I jumped on it.  This is great to get a solid idea of how flying a plane actually is.  I do have some complaints, though, which are that the controls for rudder/ground steering do not function very well for me.  One touch makes a dramatic turn, and are difficult to fine tune.  Another complaint is that the game starts having framerate issues when approaching some airports, though I cannot tell if that is my system or the game itself.I recommend finding information about the planes that you are flying to know exactly what they are doing, as this is a sim.  That way you can figure out best climb speed, role speed, best glide and so on, because they will matter in this simulator.  It will also help to learn about traffic patterns and other things like that.  Otherwise, give it a try and have fun!  I do, and I intend to invest in some flight controls for it as well.Quick tip - for most aircraft, it's throttle for altitude, pitch for speed, something most first-timers might find helpful.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												FSX Steam.Well. I saw this version of the old masterpiece at 50% reduction so I bought in. I think that for my 12€ or so it's a decent price. So, what are my impressions? I'll keep this short.Firstly, the almost 5 hour download astonished me, considering that the disc version is installed and up and runnung in less than an hour. But fair enough, I don't expect the earth for that price.When I'd tweaked the settings to the same as my disc version I took a Mooney Bravo up from Kai Tak, just for a quickie.The first thing I noticed - has anyone else? - is the torque drag (prop plane pulling to one side gradually on the run up to take off). That's cool, because you do get some of this in most real single props.The flight itself was nice and smooth, 50fps with no stutters, and no 3rd party performance booster. That's good. A lot of people want more fps than that but 50 works fine with me, whether I can get more or not - it also frees up resources to puch other settings a bit more. And I did. And it worked fine. Well done there.I've only tried Kai Tak as yet, but the Kai Tak scenery... So-o-o-o-o empty!!! I've got the scenery addon disc on my disc FSX version and wow. I'm not only comparing but saying that Steam could have included some better scenery as a part of their tweaks of the disc version. Maybe in the pipeline?I'd be interested to find out how to uninstall the military planes as I've no time in this life for such stuff. I don't shoot at people - even if it's a simulator.Last thing, a question. Do freeware addons really install into Steam FSX? Maybe I could get my sceney discs installed into this version? Help?And last but certainly not least, can I get my FSUIPC (paid) download into this program?To summarise, then, I'll recommend this simulator (I wish Steam would stop calling it a game...) as I think with future updates initial issues will be ironed out and it will be a very good app indeed. I'll also keep my disc version though because I've got too much third-party stuff installed and I like flying around a full Manhattan scenery as opposed to the one that comes with Steam.Yep, I recommend it. It's worth the 20-odd Euros, no problem.

												Plane and Simple (see what i did there? :p) FANTASTIC!Not much i can say that every other virtual pilot or FSX fan on here hasnt already, i too own a boxed version.This is possibly the best money i have ever spent on a game..... ehum SIM.All my addons have worked, Carenado, RealAir, Orbx, i hear the PMDG fix is on its way or may have been fixed with the 12.01.2015 Update.Memory is used alot more efficiently, still one bug for me on ASUS N56VM, Intel i5 @3.2ghz, Nvidia GT 630M 2GBVram.>>>>> When switching from full screen to windowed FSX hangs with a blank screen and the sound fades out. content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												I hate to refer to this as a game because most of the time I sit here staring intently trying to remember the most basic flight rules.  I have completed ground school years ago and have started getting back into learning the basics before getting into an actual plane, and although I loved FS9 and FSX, they never really worked well on Win7.  This works perfectly, no issues with graphics, updates, service packs, or even issues dealing with multiplayer.The realism is done very well in smaller planes, I can't comment on larger planes because I've never flown anything bigger than a Cessna 172, however it's a great sim to sit and brush up on skills and review procedures.  It is a simulator though.  If you want fun crashing planes and shooting down  other people in an arcade fashion, you probably won't enjoy this.  If you enjoy learning to fly, the lessons by Rob Machado offered in-game are very realistic and would cost thousands in real life.  If you want to brush up on flight, procedures, or just learn more about how planes work and mechanics of flight, this is a great game.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												The age of this game shows in its user interface (settings / controls etc) but the gameplay itself is superb. Setting up controls can be fiddly, as there are a huge number of them, but not all need to be mapped to achieve a successful flight. The in-game graphics are fabulous and especially so in some cases, and the flight characteristics of the included aircraft seem very accurate and well-modelled (to me anyway, with only 1 hours' worth of real-world flight experience!). And it's a huge amount of fun, with hundreds of different locations around the world in which to fly. At the price I paid for the game (9.99GBP) I would say that it's a complete steal. So if you like flight sims, what's stopping you?

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												If you are buying this steam version because some people said it’s smoother and gives more FPS, you’ll be disappointed because there is no enhancement whatsoever apart from the return of multiplayer. I own a boxed version and have acceleration with service parks including lots of add-ons. I get a reasonable FPS in my windows 7-64bits but just like every fsx simmer you never get enough. So when I read the feedbacks here about how it was improved, I decided to give this steam version a go. I bought it yesterday, download took like an hour or so and installation was smooth. I have made few flights now, the truth is that the only difference is that it is a combination of Gold Edition, Acceleration and Service park, and that Multiplayer is back, also uiautomationcore.dll was added to the main directory for windows 8. Performance is exactly the same as FSX Deluxe Edition with Acceleration and service park without any add-on or tweak.I have to admit that I am not very sad that I bought this steam version, but this is because my boxed version is almost cracked and I think it’s a good idea to have a digitally signed one saved at Steam library. Another thing I’m hoping for is that since this simulation is very old and therefore do not take advantages of new and better graphic cards and systems and Microsoft no longer provide updates, hopefully with steam re-releasing it now future updates will be a possibility, if not it is going to be a waste for those who have boxed version already. As for those wondering if existing addons will work. Almost all addons that you can normally copy and paste into FSX will work in Steam version, Mine worked, I have never installed any which needs installation yet. Also I installed this version in the same PC I already have FSX, both are working fine.If you want to read the reviews, from the beginning there is a separate tab for positive and negative feedbacks, which I didn’t notice. The default is positive so make sure to check the negatives also.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												So after it's FSX as we know it, only with a few goods and bads involved. The biggest good is that it's much more resource friendly than the boxed version. But that's about where the line gets drawn.The bad on the other hand is far more noticable for those that want to make FSX:SE more...relavent. Third party weather addons like Active Sky Next and REX don't work. Texture addons like FTX and REX don't work. PSPassengers and Air Hauler don't work. Even though FSUIPC reportedly now works. If you have a PMDG aircraft, don't install it into FSX:SE. Why? Doesn't work. Haven't tried using Flight Sim Commander or FSAcars yet. Crossing my fingers they work.Even so, i'd still recommend this version. Why? It's stable, it already has many bug fixes taken care of. It's actively (or so Dovetail tells us) being worked on and updated. In short, for someone who is interested in a casual flight sim, FSX:SE will work just fine. Most other aircraft mods (payware and freeware) work just fine. It's FSX. It's the old love. Enough said.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												So I may have no hours on Steam Yet, but I have a lot of experiance with the boxed verson.This game is fantastic for flight simulation, with a catch. The game is from 2006, it isn't the most realistic, the textures are outdated, so if you want realism you will have to pay the price, and that means buying numerous add ons to improve the experiance. But when all upgraded this is one of the best flight simulators on the market, with the exception of Prepar3D, which is great if you have a beefy PC and a lot of cash.If you want a better casual simulation, FSX is ok, certainly great if you have a beefy PC, X-plane offers slightly better graphics and other things.But overall, with my experiance I reccomend this to no end.EDIT:  If you already own the boxed gold edition like I do then don't use this game as a replacement yet, many third party add-ons that I have tried are not working correctly and as a result forcing me to uninstall this game untilthe issues are fixed. So I still reccomend the game but be warned that many of your add-ons will not work. I will provide a few now.CLS 747 200/300 series: No VC and sound issuesJust Flight Traffic 360: No traffic. Default general aviation only.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Cons: -Poorly detailed terrain (but you do get the entire planet).-Low speeds, even for commercial airliners.-No crash effects, kind of boring this way.-No co-pilot AI.-VERY steep learning curve, but it is a flight simulator.-No real air transit companies, but you do get real aircraft manufacturers.-Cities are lifeless.-No aircraft paint customization.Pros:-As mentioned, YOU GET THE ENTIRE PLANET!!!-Several planes and helicopters to start with, each with a few paint variants.-Every airport, big and small, seems to be included.-Confusing controls, but you can easily simplify them.-Real-time weather based on your location in-game and what it is really like there in real life.-Static weather choices as well.-Most major landmarks can be seen.-Controller support (I haven't used a joystick yet, but you can).-Air traffic controller and pilot voices, adding realism.-Can listen in on radios to hear talking between AI aircrafts and AI traffic controllers.-Great tutorials.-Multiplayer.-Sandbox mode, as well as missions-Custom difficulty (unlimited fuel, or not, etc).-Weather does affect the aircraft.-Aircrafts look good.-Well organized menus.-Able to customize your voice and callsign.-Able to customize your jets flight number.-It feels like a real airplane/helicopter.-Other aircrafts in the sky, landing or taking off.-A million ways to customize the gameplay.-Pretty good sounds, but I do recommend playing your music in the background.Verdict:-I have never actually flown a plane or helicopter before, nor will I. However, this game/simulator allows people, like me, to fly the aircrafts of their dreams! I wish that the cities were better, and the terrain looked like real terrain, but this is about the flying, and the flying is great! From fighter jets, which control like the ones in the ARMA series, to the commercial airliners, Microsoft Flight Simulator X provides a fun and exciting experience for anyone who wants it. -Minor flaws like the lifeless cities and the lack of damage/explosions does hold the game back a bit, but the flying more than makes up for it! -As I said before, the game has a huge learning curve and only real pilots will feel right at home. However, the game does provide several helpful tutorial missions that will get the rest of us in the cockpit in no time!-Overall, I think that Microsoft Flight Simulator X is a very good game. Now that it is on Steam, I recommend that anyone who likes airplanes, helicopters or simulators should give this a shot.-Balancing out the poor graphics with the amazing flying, I would give MSFSX an 8/10.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This sim comes with a unique history - it should have been dead years ago but a stubborn community kept it alive, more specifically they kept developers alive who pushed the engine harder and farther than it was intended to be pushed, with some stunningly complex and complete simulations of the flying experience being released as addons.  This new release has met with some criticism, such as dovetail didn't listen to the community and releases addons that are weak, old and overpriced.  There might be some merit in that, but in some ways the complaints are inevitable.  On the good side, the sim is 64 bit, more stable and, like it or not, the future of the software.  The actual flight mechanics are "solid", I would say(X Plane has more sophistication there), but the addons are phenomonal and more and more are becoming compatible with the Steam version as devs see which way the wind blows. You'll definitely want to get some addons at some point.  I'd go for orbx scenery over the ones being sold here(expensive but just pick the areas you want to fly), ezdok camera(there's a beta for the steam edition that works fine), Accufeel, DX10 fixer, FSFlyingSchool and some of the higher rated planes that interest you(again, the ones on steam are 'meh' at best).  You'll probably want to make a decision on what sort of experience you want - some are really into all the navigation and procedures(real world pilots use them as a decent alternative to a real flight sim), some just want to fly around and look at scenery.  They are two very different worlds.

content:

												I have owned the box copy of Flight Simulator X for about 6 years now and had come to the conclusion that I would never get it working well without dropping a lot of money on a high end system... until I got FSX:SE. With my PMDG 737 NGX add-on I used to have a very choppy experience. Now I can run with higher graphics settings AND have enough frames that the PMDG add-on (which uses a ton of CPU) is much smoother. I see about a 5-10 frames increase which is about a 25% increase in what I used to get. Even when the frames dip, the game seems to handle it better.Long story short, if you have FSX and want some more frames (which can be vital to a good landing IMO) then get FSX: SE. To me it feels like a whole new game.

												This game is awesome. Even though it is from 2006 it really delivers an amazing experience and as it is so old the community is so big and great. Tons of mods is available both freeware and payware.Pros:*The community is big and has a ton of freeware mods available**You could fly wherever you want in the big open world**The game includes missions that could be funny and good if you have to learn something**It's really realistic even without mods and with mods installed, it could even be hard to spot the difference between game and reallity*Cons:*The game is old and could not use 100% out of new computers**Even though it's pretty good detailed, the terrain and so could have been done better**The including airplanes works if you just want to have some fun, but is not so good if you are looking for a real simulator experience*---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Conclution: The game is awesome even though is old. The including planes works for having fun with, but not for simulating. So should you buy this game? YES!Recommended mods:- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -PMDG 737NGXPMDG 777NGXAerosoft A319/A320REX 4 Texture DirectGSX for FSX9 out of 10 cows! :D

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												I have probably logged a thousand hours on the original FSX....What this game could have been had the development team not been forced to shut down. In it's day, with support, it promised to be the most realistic flight simulator software avalible to the general public. Then support ended. Yet, that did not stop us die hard enthusiasts from creating libraries of add ons, modifications to dated/ glitched script and other improvements that kept the simulator relevent. Enter Steam. They bring the game back! Hooray! But no, not hooray for anyone but Steam. All of the simple fixes to make the game more enjoyable or even playable (logbook.bin, anyone?) did not even get touched. Missions still glitched to hell and back. Some airports still unplayable. Logbook issues, keybinding issues. I could go on but you get the drift here.This is a money grab by steam. Although it is cheaper than the boxed version, the developers spent minimal time fixing any of the bugs that made the boxed set so damn frustrating. Although it still works, if you are going to slap you name over a product like it is something new and improved, then improve it. Don't rely on us enthusiasts to improve the game for you. That is all.....

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Cons: -Poorly detailed terrain (but you do get the entire planet).-Low speeds, even for commercial airliners.-No crash effects, kind of boring this way.-No co-pilot AI.-VERY steep learning curve, but it is a flight simulator.-No real air transit companies, but you do get real aircraft manufacturers.-Cities are lifeless.-No aircraft paint customization.Pros:-As mentioned, YOU GET THE ENTIRE PLANET!!!-Several planes and helicopters to start with, each with a few paint variants.-Every airport, big and small, seems to be included.-Confusing controls, but you can easily simplify them.-Real-time weather based on your location in-game and what it is really like there in real life.-Static weather choices as well.-Most major landmarks can be seen.-Controller support (I haven't used a joystick yet, but you can).-Air traffic controller and pilot voices, adding realism.-Can listen in on radios to hear talking between AI aircrafts and AI traffic controllers.-Great tutorials.-Multiplayer.-Sandbox mode, as well as missions-Custom difficulty (unlimited fuel, or not, etc).-Weather does affect the aircraft.-Aircrafts look good.-Well organized menus.-Able to customize your voice and callsign.-Able to customize your jets flight number.-It feels like a real airplane/helicopter.-Other aircrafts in the sky, landing or taking off.-A million ways to customize the gameplay.-Pretty good sounds, but I do recommend playing your music in the background.Verdict:-I have never actually flown a plane or helicopter before, nor will I. However, this game/simulator allows people, like me, to fly the aircrafts of their dreams! I wish that the cities were better, and the terrain looked like real terrain, but this is about the flying, and the flying is great! From fighter jets, which control like the ones in the ARMA series, to the commercial airliners, Microsoft Flight Simulator X provides a fun and exciting experience for anyone who wants it. -Minor flaws like the lifeless cities and the lack of damage/explosions does hold the game back a bit, but the flying more than makes up for it! -As I said before, the game has a huge learning curve and only real pilots will feel right at home. However, the game does provide several helpful tutorial missions that will get the rest of us in the cockpit in no time!-Overall, I think that Microsoft Flight Simulator X is a very good game. Now that it is on Steam, I recommend that anyone who likes airplanes, helicopters or simulators should give this a shot.-Balancing out the poor graphics with the amazing flying, I would give MSFSX an 8/10.

												I owned this game on disc for many years and recently changed to steam edition. I will review the improvements. Firstly, I have noticed how the optimization is far better, I am getting around 20 fps more! It also comes with more missions (originally from the acceleration version which I didn't have) and there are around 10 more! The good thing about FSX is that no matter how experienced you are, you can learn from this game by starting small by using VFR all the way to using IFR!

												As a pilot in the real world FSX was the signal best investment in training aids and tools I have made. The Steam Edition comes with reqired tweeks an updates that did not come with the last production run of the DVD virsion. Although there are some game elements I hezatate to call it a came, it is deffently a simulator that can be set to basic to just short of full motion avaition training device. I still us FSX: Steam Edition to fly a route before I go out on real flight. Some times I even try to fly a flight that was canceled and ussally find out why canceling was the right choise.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												It's a pretty damn good game, however the base game isn't great. You really need addons if you want to get a good experience. Free ones are available however are unreliable and if you don't download them correctly you can destroy your game (I did that, thus why I've bought it on steam). The good ones are pretty pricey and can also ruin your game if not installed properly. In total it can cost you over £50 and that's not including the accessories (e.g. joystick) you'll need to get the full experience. Don't be fooled by the trailer, the game looks like it was made in 2004 (because it was made in 2004) which is why you really need addons.
